channel.title: The Mastermind Fake-Claim Problem
channel.description:
* Knight
If you don't get flirted or coldsteeled by the real Knight, this is a good fake claim.
* Obs * Princess * Sheriff
You'd think these classes would be decent fake-claims because like MM, they are Special/Investigative and not occupy immune, but Obs is impossible to fake. Princess gets outed as soon as King dies, and Sheriff gets outed because there's usually two real Sheriffs.
* Phys
Very easy to write fake logs for, but almost every game has two real Phys.
* CW
As impossible to fake as Obs, since you can't fake the N1 swap that every good CW performs.
* Butler * Drunk
Impossible to fake and you have nothing in common with these classes.
* Hunter
Unique, you can't fake claim it when there's a real Hunter and you have no way of knowing if there is before it's too late.
* Mystic * Noble
Impossible to fake.
# Conclusion:
Knight is the only well-rounded **BD** fakeclaim for Mastermind. All the others require more luck than social manipulation to maintain your cover, like there not being 2 real Sheriffs or you randomly converted one N1 and he changed his claim upon becoming Assassin.
I believe this is another illustration of why we need new BD classes in the game.

item.title: The Mastermind Fake-Claim Problem
item.dc:creator: Sketch
item.description:
I’ve been reading along with this thread for a while and want to throw in my 2 cents about fakeclaiming.

The reality is that BD get occupied all the time. Sometimes you are unable to visit somebody. Things go wrong where your action doesn’t go through, and that is perfectly normal. However, when you are claiming Butler or Drunk and cannot claim “occupied”, you remove a vital tool in your kit to obfuscate. So you must either write fake information or claim you could not visit them. You lost 1 of your 3 tools to work with when creating a fake will, and be forced to input fake info that could catch the eye of BD. The biggest mistake you can do as scum is to never include “occupied” or “unable to visit” in any of your journals.

Claiming any occupation immune role like Butler/Butler is incredibly limiting and is strictly a -EV play in most games. Not only is your ability one that gives feedback and is generally easy to prove, the passive of real Butlers/Drunk prevent you from writing “occupied” in your journal.

Drunk is definitely worse of a claim than Butler because of the royal blood passive. Almost all Drunk claims are polarized to Drunk/Alcoholic/Assassin. Even Assassin’s may be wary of claiming their previous role of Alcoholic if they haven’t debauched anybody in a while.

Claiming an Investigative as the MM is your best bet in the grand picture. It allows you to claim occupied, AND you can turn things in your favor by mislynching in MYLO with false accusations. Using your claim as an Investigative gives you a 4th tool in your toolbox. It’s more difficult to mislynch somebody when you are claiming Physician/Butler than when you are claiming Princess/Sheriff as calling a BD out as scum with fake results.

I personally claim Observer as MM. Princess and Sheriff are fine claims, but I enjoy the challenge and flexibility of the Observer. Observer is the hardest role to play in the game, and it is the hardest to fake. But if you pay enough attention to the game, make educated guesses with where people are going, are good at lying and CC’ing, and have a little bit of luck as well, Observer can be a grand slam claim for MM in any game.

item.title: The Mastermind Fake-Claim Problem
item.dc:creator: Vandalay
item.description:
Shrimpy:

Okay I see your point. Which I think is basically it’s not worth recording data from 100 matches to figure out spawn rates to get a significant advantage?

My point is the significance of the advantage is probably very very low. It’s likely the difference between turning a 50/50 into a 55/45 off of statistics alone, and quite likely trying for it is more likely to cause you to miss something in the logs/chat etc… that could have actually solved it. I don’t think published or unpublished it would have a significant advantage in winrates in either direction.

That being said, I probably lean more towards transparency over secrecy with regards to those rates. Just on a general principle that if someone cares they will find out and it creates more of an image of fairness for it to be known, even if the information is worthless strategically.
